choices.text: Variably enveloped viruses with a complex symmetry

questions.solution:
Coronaviruses are enveloped helically symmetrical viruses.

Being enveloped contributes to their lipid solvent susceptibility. This is the reason alcohol-based hand sanitizers and soaps are used. The lipid membrane dissolution and protein denaturation by ethanol lead to membrane disruption and inhibition of metabolism.

The coronaviridiae have a single unsegmented ss (+) RNA, which is the largest genome among RNA viruses. They are about 120- 160 nm in size and contain a helical nucleocapsid. A total of seven human coronaviruses have been identified:

Name Illness
SARS-CoV-2 COVID-19
SARS-CoV Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)
MERS-CoV Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS)
HCoV-NL63 Usually mild respiratory illness
HCoV-229E
HCoV-OC43
HKU1

The image given below shows the coronavirus.

Covid-19 was declared a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC) on 30 January 2020 and as a pandemic on 11th March 2020.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic man presents with difficulty breathing, cough, and fever. He came back after visiting his son in New York, 10 days ago. His SpO2 is 89%. HRCT shows bilateral, multilobar ground-glass opacification. What is the receptor used by the likely causative organism to gain entry into the cells?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing breathlessness, fever, and cough with a low oxygen saturation and ground-glass opacities on HRCT is indicative of COVID-19 caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE-2) is the specific functional receptor for SARS-CoV-2 in human cells. 

ACE2 is expressed in nearly all human organs in varying degrees. In the respiratory system, ACE2 is mainly expressed by the type 2 alveolar epithelial cells in the highest quantity. Hence, the primary target of SARS-CoV-2 is type 2 alveolar cells.

The functional receptor for SARS-CoV (SARS 2002) is also ACE 2.

Note: Dipeptidylpeptidase 4 is the functional receptor for MERS-CoV (MERS 2012).

questions.text: Which viral structure determines the infectious nature and host specificity of SARS-CoV-2?
questions.solution:
Spike protein (marked as 1 in the image) determines the infectious nature and host specificity of SARS-CoV-2. 

The spike protein also referred to as the CoV S protein is one of the key components determining virus virulence, tissue tropism, and host range. The coronavirus spike protein mediates coronavirus entry into host cells. Each spike protein has two distinct subunits S1 and S2. 

  • S1 subunit is responsible for binding to the specific receptor (ACE 2) on the host cell surface facilitating viral attachment to the surface of target cells.
  • S2 subunit drives the fusion of the viral and host cell membranes.

The host protease enzymes, mainly transmembrane protease serine-type 2 (TMPRSS2) cleave the spike protein. This activates the spike protein to induce virus-cell membrane fusion at the cell surface and allows the entry of coronaviruses into the host cell.

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios is unlikely for transmission of SARS-CoV-2?

choices.text: A gym trainer transmitted the virus to his client following a sudden, involuntary cough.
A librarian got infected from a reader through the share and exchange of books.
A resident transmitted the virus to his neighbour who entered the same apartment lift after a few hours.
A thalassemic girl got infected following routine blood transfusion.

questions.solution:
Blood transfusion is not a mode of transmission of SARS-CoV-2.

Option A: Droplet transmission 

  • A type of direct transmission
  • Occurs when someone coughs, sneezes, speaks, or spits
  • Virus-containing droplets from the infected person travel shortly in the air directly contact another person’s conjunctiva, oral or nasal mucosa
  • Limited to about 6 feet distance between the source and the host
  • Particle size is 5-10 µm in diameter

Option B: Fomite transmission 

  • A type of indirect transmission
  • Objects other than water or food contaminated by infectious agents - clothes, towels, linen, cups, spoons, pencils, books, toys, door handles, taps, etc.
  • Transmission occurs when one touches the contaminated objects and touches his mouth, nose, or eyes

Option C: Airborne - droplet nuclei transmission 

  • A type of indirect transmission
  • Droplet nuclei - dried residue of droplets of size <5µm that are generated by the evaporation of droplets coughed or sneezed into the air and by a variety of atomizing devices
  • Remain infectious when suspended in the air for some time (typically hours)
  • Transmission occurs when one inhales droplet nuclei/aerosols containing the virus in sufficient quantity

questions.text: A relative of a COVID-19 positive man, who came in his contact yesterday, reported to the flu clinic. Within how many days is he most likely to develop the disease?
questions.solution:
The incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 infection ranges from 1-14 days so he is most likely to develop the disease after this period. The median incubation period is around 4-6 days. 

The incubation period is defined as the time interval between invasion by an infectious agent and appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease.

questions.text: Covid 19 outbreak is a type of which of the following kinds of the epidemic?
questions.solution:
The outbreak of COVID-19 is an example of a propagated epidemic.

The propagated epidemic results from person-to-person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. Other examples of this type include hepatitis A and polio.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: What is not included in the definition of a suspect case of SARS-CoV-2?
questions.solution:
All of the given symptoms are included in the definition of a suspect case of SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 except convulsions.

As per WHO and MOHFW, a suspect case is defined as:

  1. A person who meets the clinical and epidemiological criteria-
    1. Clinical criteria:
      • Acute onset of fever AND cough; OR
      • Acute onset of any 3 or more of the following: fever, cough, general weakness/ fatigue, headache, myalgia, sore throat, coryza, dyspnoea, anorexia/nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, altered mental status.
    2. Epidemiological criteria: A person present in any of the following settings for 14 days prior to symptom onset-
      • Residing or working in an area with a high risk of transmission of virus OR
      • Residing or travel to an area with community transmission OR
      • Working in any healthcare setting
  2. A patient with severe acute respiratory illness with-
    • history of fever or measured fever of ≥38 C° along with cough
    • onset within the last 10 days
    • requiring hospitalization
  3. An asymptomatic person not meeting epidemiologic criteria with a positive SARS-CoV-2 antigen-RDT.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a probable case of SARS-CoV-2?

choices.text: An asymptomatic contact of a probable case with a positive COVID-19 rapid antigen test.
A person with acute onset fever and cough who is a contact of a confirmed case.
A suspect case with positive chest radiological findings suggestive of COVID-19 disease.
A person with recent onset of anosmia or ageusia in the absence of any other identified cause.

questions.solution:
An asymptomatic contact of a probable case with a positive COVID-19 rapid antigen test is considered as a confirmed case, and not a probable case.

Probable case is defined as: 

  1. A patient who meets clinical criteria and is a contact of a probable or confirmed case, or linked to a COVID-19 cluster.
  2. A suspect case with chest imaging showing findings suggestive of COVID-19 disease.
  3. A person with recent onset of anosmia or ageusia in the absence of any other identified cause.
  4. Death, not otherwise explained, in an adult with respiratory distress preceding death and was a contact of a probable or confirmed case or linked to a COVID-19 cluster.

Confirmed case is defined as:

  1. A person with a positive Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT) including RT-PCR or any other similar test approved by ICMR.
  2. A person with a positive COVID-19 rapid antigen test and meeting either the probable case definition or suspect criteria.
  3. An asymptomatic person with a positive COVID-19 rapid antigen test who is a contact of a probable or confirmed case.

questions.text: Which of the following people would you not classify as a high risk contact of SARS-CoV2?

choices.text: A family member who lives in the same household as the patient
A doctor who examined the patient with a surgical mask and gloves
A passenger in the same bus as a symptomatic patient for 6 hours and the patient later tested positive
A sanitary worker who cleaned the linens of the patient

questions.solution:
A person traveling in the same environment and not having significant exposure to the confirmed case is not classified as a high-risk contact.

A contact of COVID-19 is a person living in the same household or having direct physical contact with the patient/infectious secretions without appropriate PPE or a person who was in a closed environment or at a distance of within 1 meter of a COVID-19 case.

High-risk contacts:

  • Touched body fluids of the patient
  • Had direct contact with the body of the patient during the physical examination without proper PPE
  • Touched or cleaned the linens, clothes, or dishes of the patient
  • Lives in the same household as the patient
  • Comes in close contact (within 1 meter) with the patient without necessary precautions
  • A passenger in close proximity with the symptomatic patient for 6 hours and the patient later tested positive


Low-risk contacts:

  • Shared the same space but does not have a high-risk exposure to the confirmed case.
  • Travelled in the same environment but does not have a high-risk exposure to the confirmed case.

questions.text: You would classify all of the following patients as having major risk factors for severe COVID-19 except:

choices.text: A 19 year old female undergoing dialysis for CKD
A 49 year old male who has recently undergone liver transplantation
A  42 year old man who had malaria 2 months ago
A  65  year old male with no comorbidities

questions.solution:
A middle-aged man who had malaria 2 months ago is not at major risk of developing severe COVID-19 disease.

The major risk factors for severe COVID-19 are: 

  • Increasing age (>60 years) 
  • Underlying non-communicable diseases       
    • Cardiac disease 
    • Chronic lung disease 
    • Cerebrovascular disease 
    • Hypertension
    • Diabetes
    • Obesity
    • Chronic kidney disease
    • Immune suppression
    • Cancer

questions.text:
A woman presents with breathlessness and hemoptysis since yesterday. Examination findings are given below. CT scan shows localised ground-glass opacity in the left posterior lobe of the lung. What is the likely diagnosis?

Pulse- 96/min,

BP- 118/68 mmHg,

Temperature- 100.3 F

RR- 15 cpm

SpO2- 82% on room air
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID-19. Hemoptysis is one of the atypical manifestations of COVID-19 and it may be present with more common features such as breathlessness, fever, and cough. CT-finding of localized ground-glass opacity is also supportive of the diagnosis.

Other atypical manifestations of COVID-19 include:

  • Respiratory-
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemoptysis
  • Cardiac-
    • Myocardial infarction
    • Myocarditis
    • Pericarditis
    • Pericardial effusion
  • Neurological-
    • Stroke
    • Guillain‐Barre Syndrome
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxic encephalopathy
    • Acute hemorrhagic necrotizing encephalopathy
    • Olfactory and taste disorders
  • Gastrointestinal-
    • Diarrhea
    • Nausea
    • Vomiting
    • Abdominal pain
  • Ocular-
    • Conjunctivitis
    • Epiphora
  • Cutaneous-
    • Erythematous rash
    • Widespread urticaria
    • Chickenpox‐like vesicles
    • Localized pruritic lesions
    • Petechial skin rash

Option A: Tuberculosis would have a more chronic history and radiologically appears as dense, homogeneous parenchymal consolidation in subpleural sites of lower and middle lobes.

Option B: In necrotising pneumonia, CT imaging is likely to show distinct areas of low attenuation with decreased parenchymal enhancement representing liquefaction.

Option D: Invasive aspergillosis is likely to occur in the setting of immunosuppression. The associated ground glass opacity, occurring due to hemorrhage, surrounds a pulmonary nodule and is known as the halo sign.

questions.text: What is the most common lung pathology seen during the autopsy of COVID-19 patients?
questions.solution:
Diffuse alveolar damage is the most common lung pathology noted during the autopsy of COVID-19 patients. 

COVID-19 related histopathological changes in the lungs include: 

  1. Diffuse alveolar damage
  2. Hyaline membrane formation
  3. Desquamation of pneumocytes
  4. Fibrin deposits in lungs
  5. Inflammation with mononuclear cells

Note: Diffuse alveolar damage is not specific to COVID-19. It may be seen in all cases of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) including pneumonia, burns, near drowning, etc

questions.text:
You are posted as an intern in casualty. An elderly 60-year-old man is brought to you with complaints of chest pain. He has tested positive for COVID. Which of the following features will prompt you to get this patient admitted to dedicated COVID Health Centre?

A. Respiratory rate of 25/min
B. SpO2 93%
C. Multiple comorbidities
D. Chest pain
E. Age
questions.solution: A, B, C & E are clinical criteria of admission under COVID-19 ward.
